web.name: Pay attention to look and feel
web.description: We have all been reading those warnings about phishing attacks that make us believe we are aware and therefore resistant against them. While in fact, it only takes one unaware minute on the internet to be affected by a phishing attack. If you keep one thing about "Phishing Resistance" in mind, let it be the fact, that you always pay general attention to the look and feel of websites. If a site is a bit unprofessional, unexpected or suspicious you better come back to "Phishing Resistance" and refresh your knowledge, instead of falling for a phishing attack.

web.name: Where is the website comming from?
web.description: The URL (Uniform Ressource Locator) or more commonly links of websites tell you where it comes from. It's a first indication of phishing if the domain name does not match the name of the displayed page. The domain name consists of the words inside the URL between the 'https://' and the ending like '.com', '.de' or '.org'

web.name: Beware domain permutation
web.description: Website URLs are unique and well defined to each character.  It could be faked easily by altering a letter or switching some words so that they look very similar to the original one, but lead to a different website instead. An example would be the faked link https://micosofts.com where an 's' was appended which looks unproblematic on first sight but could be a malicious website instead. Be careful with familiar looking links too.

web.name: Spoofed websites
web.description: Faked websites that look exaclty like the original, but instead of signing into your user account, you will send your account credentials to the attackers. After you have passed them your login details, they will redirect you to the original page and sign you in. Therefore you wouldn't even notice the attack until it has caused damage. To prevent this from happening, use your own bookmarked links or a trustworthy searchengine to access the login.

web.name: Never sign in with http (unencrypted). Use https (encrypted) instead!
web.description: The lock in your browser near the URL indicates if the connection is encrypted or not. The open lock signals an unencrypted http connection where all your data is transmitted like an open book. Never enter passwords on a website with a open lock. If you see a closed lock in your browser, an encrypted https connection is used and your passwords arrive safe on the other end.

web.name: Trust your own antivirus software
web.description: There are malicious websites which say that your computer was infected by a virus. Websites have very little insight about your computer if your system is healthy and up to date. If they say your system is infected by a virus and their software will cure it, stay calm, a website can't scan your whole computer. Use your own antivirus software to scan for malware instead.

web.name: Question everything
web.description:
False lottery wins, money offers, virus attacks or blackmails. Those things are often used by attackers to put people under pressure, so they would act imprudent. If you find yourself in one of these situations, just stay calm.
Nothing is for free and you are propably not the 1,000,000th user winning a reward. Furthermore remember doing your system updates and trust your operating system. It will protect your data from others.

mail.name: Fake E-mail address and spoofing
mail.description: To simplify how E-mails work: See e-mails just like regular letters made out of paper. Usually the postman delivers all letters into your mailbox. However this doesn't restrain anyone else from creating a fake letter, writing any name in the senders field and putting it into your mailbox as well. E-mails work very similar so be sceptical with the senders field.

mail.name: Verifying the sender of an e-mail
mail.description: The only way to check the authenticity of the sender is to verify it by SPF or DKIM. The fastest way of checking if a mail passed one of these protocolls and is authentic, is to view the source code of the e-mail. In most e-mail applications this can be done with a button, stating 'show original', 'show source' or something similar. If you go through all this text, watch out for spf=pass or dkim=pass and if you see one of them, the sender of the mail is authentic.

mail.name: Compressed Links
mail.description: There are third party services to reduce the length of a hyperlink but they make them unreadable so you don't know where they are leading to.

mail.name: Drive by download
mail.description: Upon visiting a website, clicking a link or accessing e-mail attachements, malware could be downloaded in the background without you noticing. Instead of clicking a link you just gave the permission for the download instead and that is a reason why compressed links should be avoided.

mail.name: Spam
mail.description: E-mails you don't have requested. Most of them are harmless but still unwanted. The reason why you get spam could be a security leak of a service you are using or furthermore untrustfull services could have sold your data to 3rd parties. Another reason could be guessing e-mail addresses by computationally combining firstnames, lastnames and a mail provider.

mail.name: Dangerous Documents
mail.description: So called file less attacks are common documents like PDFs or Microsoft Office documents with malicious program code injected. If you open a file, scan it with your antivirus software first.

mail.name: Urgent Notifications and Confirmation
mail.description: Account validation and customer service. These are reasons why valid companies send out authentic e-mails. You should always ask yourself: 'Did I request the e-mail?' When in doubt go to the official page by a search engine and check yourself.
